div.p: THE COUNTRY GIRL, A COMEDY, (Altered from WYCHERLEY) As it is ACTED at the Theatre-Royal in Drury-Lane.
DUBLIN: Printed for W. and W. SMITH, J. HOEY, Sen. J MURPHY, W. WHITESTONE, H. SAUNDERS, D. CHAMBERLAINE, J. POTTS, J. HOEY, Jun. J. WILLIAMS, O. ADAMS & T. RYDER, and W. COLLES.

div.head: Advertiſement.
div.p: THE Deſire of ſhewing Miſs REYNOLDS to Advantage, was the firſt Motive for attempting an Alteration of WYCHERLEY'S COUNTRY WIFE. Tho' near half of the following Play is new written, the Alterer claims no Merit, but his Endeavour to clear one of our moſt celebrated Comedies from Immorality and Obſcenity. He thought himſelf bound to preſerve as much of the Original, as could be preſented to an Audience of theſe Times without Offence; and if this Wanton of CHARLES'S Days is now ſo reclaimed, as to become innocent without being inſiped, the preſent Editor will not think his Time ill employed, which has enabled him to add ſome little Variety to the Entertainments of the Publick. There ſeems indeed an abſolute Neceſſity for reforming many Plays of our moſt eminent Writers: For no kind of Wit ought to be received as an Excuſe for for Immorality, nay it becomes ſtill more dangerous in proportion as it is more witty—Without ſuch a Reformation, our Engliſh Comedies muſt be reduced to a very ſmall Number, and would pall by a too frequent Repetition, or what is worſe, continue ſhameleſs in ſpite of publick Diſapprobation.
Whatever fate this Play may have in the Cloſet, it is much indebted to the Preformers for its favourable Reception upon the Stage.

div.stage: Harcourt tying up his ſtockings, and Belville ſitting by him.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: HA, ha, ha! and ſo you are in love, nephew, not reaſonably and gallantly, as a young gentleman ought, but ſighingly, miſerably ſo—not content to be ankle-deep, you have ſous'd over head and ears—ha, Dick?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: I am pretty much in that condition, indeed, uncle. [ſighs.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Nay, never bluſh at it—when I was of your age, I was aſham'd too;—but three years at College, and half a one at Paris, methinks ſhould have cur'd you of that unfaſhionable weakneſs—modeſty.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Could I have releas'd myſelf from that, I had, perhaps, been at this inſtant happy in the poſſeſſion of what I muſt deſpair now ever to obtain—heigho!

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! very fooliſh indeed.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Don't laugh at me, uncle; I am fooliſh, I know; but, like other fools, I deſerve to be pitied.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Prithee don't talk of pity; how can I help you?—for this country girl of yours is certainly married.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: No, no—I won't believe it; ſhe is not married, nor ſhe ſhan't, If I can help it.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Well ſaid, modeſty;—with ſuch a ſpirit you can help yourſelf, Dick, without my aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: But you muſt encourage, and adviſe me too, or I ſhall never make any thing of it.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Provided the girl is not married; for I never, never encourage young men to covet their neighbours wives.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: My heart aſſures me, that ſhe is not married.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: O to be ſure, your heart is much to be rely'd upon—but to convince you that I have a fellow-feeling of your diſtreſs, and that I am as nearly ally'd to you in misſortunes as in relationſhip—you muſt know—

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: What, uncle? you alarm me!

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: That I am in love too.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Miſerably in love.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: That's charming.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: And my miſtreſs is juſt going to be married to another.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Better, and better.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: I knew my fellow-ſufferings would pleaſe you; but now prepare for the wonderful wonder of wonders!

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Well!—

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: My miſtreſs is in the ſame houſe with yours.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: What, are you in love with Peggy too?[riſing from his chair.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Well ſaid, jealouſy.—No, no, ſet your heart at reſt.—Your Peggy is too young, and too ſimple for me—I muſt have one a little more knowing, a little better bred, juſt old enough to ſee the difference between me and a coxcomb, ſpirit enough to break from a brother's engagements, and chuſe for herſelf.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: You don't mean Alithea, who is to be married to Mr. Sparkiſh?

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Can't I be in love with a lady that is going to be married to another, as well as you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: But Sparkiſh is your friend.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p:
Prithee don't call him my friend; he can be
nobody's friend, not even his own—He would thruſt himſelf into my acquaintance, would introduce me to his miſtreſs, tho' I have told him again and again that I was in love with her, which inſtead of ridding me of him, has made him only ten times more troubleſome—and me really in love—He ſhould ſuffer for his ſelfſufficiency.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: 'Tis a conceited puppy!—And what ſucceſs with the lady?

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: No great hopes,—and yet, if I could defer the marriage a few days, I ſhould not deſpair;—her honour, I am confident, is her only attachment to my rival—ſhe can't like Sparkiſh, and if I can work upon his credulity, a credulity which even popery would be aſham'd of, I may yet have the chance of throwing ſixes upon the dice to ſave me.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Nothing can ſave me.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: No, not if you whine and ſigh, when you ſhould be exerting every thing that is man about you. I have ſent Sparkiſh, who is admitted at all hours in the houſe, to know how the land lies for you, and if ſhe is not married already.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: How cruel you are—you raiſe me up with one hand, and then knock me down with the other.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Well, well, ſhe ſhan't be married. [knocking at the door.] This is Sparkiſh, I ſuppoſe; don't drop the leaſt hint of your paſſion to him; if you do, you may as well advertiſe it in the publick papers.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: I'll be careful.—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: An odd ſort of a perſon, from the country I believe, who calls himſelf Moody, wants to ſee you, Sir; but as I did not know him, I ſaid you were not at home, but would return directly; and ſo will I too, ſaid he, very ſhort and ſurly! and away he went, mumbling to himſelf.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Very well, Will.—I'll ſee him when he comes. [Exit Servant.] Moody call to ſee me!—He has ſomething more in his head than making me a viſit—'tis to complain of you, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: How can he know me?

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: We muſt ſuppoſe the worſt, and be prepared for him—tell me all you know of this ward of his, this Peggy—Peggy what's her name?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Thrift, Thrift, uncle.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir Thomas Thrift's daughter, of Hampſhire, and left very young, under the guardianſhip of my old companion and acquaintance, Jack Moody.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Your companion!—he's old enough to be your father.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Thank you, nephew—he has greatly the advantage of me in years, as well as wiſdom—When I firſt launched from the univerſity, into this ocean of London—he was the greateſt rake in it; I knew him well, for near two years, but all of a ſudden he tooka freak (a very prudent one) of retiring wholly into the country.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: There he gain'd ſuch an aſcendency over the odd diſpoſition of his neighbour, Sir Thomas, that he left him ſole guardian to his daughter, who forfeits half her fortune, if ſhe does not marry with his conſent—there's the devil, uncle.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: And are you ſo young, ſo fooliſh, and ſo much in love, that you would take her with half her value? ha, nephew?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: I'll take her with any thing—with nothing.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: What! ſuch an unaccompliſh'd, aukward, ſilly creature—he has ſcarce taught her to write—ſhe has ſeen nobody to converſe with, but the country people about 'em; ſo ſhe can do nothing but dangle her arms, look gawky, turn her toes in, and talk broad Hampſhire.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Don't abuſe her ſweet ſimplicity—had you but heard her talk, as I have done, from the garden-wall in the country, by moon-light.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Romeo and Juliet, I proteſt, ha, ha, ha! Ariſe fair ſun, and kill the envious—ha, ha, ha! How often have you ſeen this fair Capulet?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p:
I ſaw her three times in the country, and ſpoke to her twice; I have leap'd an orchard-wall, like Romeo, to come at her, play'd the balcony-ſcene, from an old ſummer-houſe in the garden; and if I loſe her, I
will find out an apothecary, and play the tomb-ſcene too, for I cannot bear to be croſs'd in love.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Dick!—this ſpirit muſt produce ſomething—but has the old dragon ever caught you ſighing at her?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Never in the country; he ſaw me yeſterday kiſſing my hand to her, from the new tavern-window that looks upon the back of his houſe, and immediately drove her from it, and faſten'd up the window-ſhutters.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Very well, Will. I'll go up to 'em.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: I hear Sparkiſh coming up—take care of what I told you—not a word of Peggy;—hear his intelligence, and make uſe of it, without ſeeming to mind it.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Mum, mum, uncle.

sp.speaker: Spar.
sp.p: O, my dear Harcourt, I ſhall die with laughing—I have ſuch news for thee—ha, ha, ha!—What, your nephew too, and a little dumpiſh or ſo—you have been giving him a lecture upon oeconomy, I ſuppoſe—you, who never had any, can beſt deſcribe the evils that ariſe from the want of it.—I never mind my own affairs, not I.—I hear, Mr. Belville, you have got a pretty ſnug houſe, with a bow-window that looks into the Park, and a back-door that goes out into it.—Very convenient, and well imagin'd—no young handſome fellow ſhould be without one—you may be always ready there, like a ſpider in his web, to ſeize upon ſtray'd women of quality.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: As you us'd to do—you vain fellow you—prithee don't teach my nephew your abandoned tricks—he is a modeſt young man, and you muſt not ſpoil him.—

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: May be ſo; but his modeſty has done ſome miſchief at our houſe—my ſurly, jealous brother-in-law ſaw that modeſt young gentleman caſting a wiſhful eye at his forbidden fruit from the new tavern window.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: You miſtake the perſon, Mr. Sparkiſh, I don't know what young lady you mean.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Explain yourſelf, Sparkiſh, you muſt miſtake—Dick has never ſeen the girl.

sp.speaker: Spar.
sp.p: I don't ſay he has; I only tell you what Moody ſays. Beſides, he went to the tavern himſelf, and enquir'd of the waiter, who din'd in the backroom,—No. 4,—and they told him it was Mr. Belville, your nephew—that's all I know of the matter, or deſire to know of it—faith.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: He kiſs'd his hand, indeed, to your lady, Alithea, and is more in love with her than you are, and very near as much as I am; ſo look about you, ſuch a youth may be dangerous.

sp.speaker: Spar.
sp.p: The more danger the more honour, I defy you both—win her and wear her, if you can—Dolus an virtus in love as well as in war—tho' you muſt be expeditious, faith; for I believe, if I don't change my mind, I ſhall marry her to-morrow or the day after.—Have you no honeſt clergyman, Harcourt, no fellow-collegian to recommend to me to do the buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Nothing ever ſure was ſo lucky. [aſide.] Why, faith, I have, Sparkiſh—my brother, a twinbrother, Ned Harcourt, will be in town to day, and proud to attend your commands—I am a very generous rival, you ſee, to lend my brother to marry the woman I love?

sp.speaker: Spar.
sp.p: And ſo am I too, to let your brother come ſo near us—But Ned ſhall be the man; poor Alithea grows impatient—I can't put off the evil day any longer—I fancy the brute, her brother, has a mind to marry his country ideot at the ſame time.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: How, country idiot, Sir!

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Taiſez vous bete. [aſide to Belv.] I thought he had been married already.

sp.speaker: Spar.
sp.p: No, no, he's not married, that's the joke of it.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: No, no, he is not married.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Hold your tongue— [elbowing Belville.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p:
Not he—I have the fineſt ſtory to tell you—by the by, he intends calling upon you, for he aſk'd me where you liv'd, to complain of modeſty there—He pick'd up an old raking acquaintance of his, as we came along together—Will. Frankly, who ſaw him with his girl, ſculking and mu •• led up, at the play laſt night—he plagu'd him much about matrimony, and his
being aſham'd to ſhew himſelf; ſwore he was in love with his wife, and intended to cuckold him; do you, cry'd Moody, folding his arms, and ſcouling with his eyes thus—You muſt have more wit than you us'd to have—Beſides, if you have as much as you think you have, I ſhall be out of your reach, and this profligate metropolis, in leſs than a week—Moody would feign have got rid of him, but the other held him by the ſleeve, ſo I left 'em; rejoic'd moſt luxuriouſly to ſee the poor devil tormented.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: I thought you ſaid, juſt now, that he was not married—is not that a contradiction, Sir?

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Why, it is a kind of a one—but conſidering your modeſty, and your ignorance of the young lady, you are pretty tolerably inquiſitive methinks, ha, Harcourt! ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Pooh, pooh! don't talk to that baby, tell me all you know.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: You muſt know, my boody of a brother-in-law hath brought up this ward of his (a good fortune let me tell you) as he coops up, and fattens his chickens, for his own eating—he is plaguy jealous of her, and was very ſorry that he could not marry her in the country, without coming up to town; which he could not do on account of ſome writings or other; ſo what does my gentleman, he perſuades that poor ſilly girl by breaking a ſix-pence, or ſome nonſenſe or another, that they are to all intents married in heaven; but that the laws require the ſigning of articles, and the church ſervice to compleat their union—ſo he has made her call him huſband, and bud, which ſhe conſtantly does, and he calls her wife, and gives out ſhe is married, that ſhe may not look after younger fellows, nor younger fellows after her, egad; ha, ha, ha! and all won't do.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Thank you, Sir—what heav'nly news, uncle!

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: What an ideot you are nephew! And ſo then you make but one trouble of it; and are both to be tack'd together the ſame day?

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p:
No▪ no, he can▪t be married this week; he damns the lawyers for keeping him in town;—beſides
I am out of favour; and he is continually ſnarling at me, and abuſing me, for not being jealous. [knocking at the door.] There he is—I muſt not be ſeen with you, for he'll ſuſpect ſomething; I'll go with your nephew to his houſe, and we'll wait for you, and make a viſit to my wife that is to be, and, perhaps, we ſhall ſhew young Modeſty here a ſight of Peggy too.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, here's the ſtrange odd ſort of a gentleman come again, and I have ſhewn him into the fore-parlour.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: That muſt he Moody! well ſaid, Will, an odd ſort of a ſtrange gentleman indeed; we'll ſtep into the next room 'till he comes into this, and then you may have him all to yourſelf—much good may do you. [Sparkiſh going, returns.] Remember that he is married, or he'll ſuſpect me of betraying him.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Shew him up Will. Now muſt I prepare myſelf to ſee a very ſtrange, tho' a very natural metamorphoſis—a once high-ſpirited, handſome, welldreſs'd, raking prodigal of the town, ſunk into a ſurly, ſuſpicious oeconomical, country ſloven—le voila.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Mr. Harcourt, your humble ſervant—have you forgot me?

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: What, my old friend Jack Moody! by thy long abſence from the town, the grumneſs of thy countenance, and the ſlovenlyneſs of thy habit, I ſhould give thee joy—you are certainly married.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: My long ſtay in the country will excuſe my dreſs, and I have a ſuit of law, that brings me up to town, and puts me out of humour—beſides, I muſt give Sparkiſh ten thouſand pounds to-morrow to take my ſiſter off my hands.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Your ſiſter is very much obliged to you—being ſo much older than her, you have taken upon you the authority of a father, and have engaged her to a coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: I have, and to oblige her—nothing but coxcombs, or debauchees are the favourites now-a-days, and a coxcomb is rather the more innocent animal of the two.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: She has ſenſe, and taſte, and can't like him; ſo you muſt anſwer for the conſequences.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: When ſhe is out of my hands, her huſband muſt look to conſequences. He's a faſhionable fool, and will cut his horns kindly.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: And what is to ſecure your worſhip from conſequences—I did not expect marriage from ſuch a rake—one that knew the town ſo well: fye, fye, Jack.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: I'll tell you my ſecurity—I have married no London wife.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: That's all one—that grave circumſpection in marrying a country wife, is like refuſing a deceitful, pamper'd, Smithfield-jade, to go and be cheated by a friend in the country.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: I wiſh the devil had both him and his ſimile. [aſide.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Well, never grumble about it; what's done can't be undone; is your wife handſome and young?

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: She has little beauty but her youth, nothing to brag of but her health, and no attraction but her modeſty—wholeſome, homely, and houſewifely—that's all.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: You talk as like a grazier, as you look, Jack—why did you not bring her to town before to be taught ſomething?

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Which ſomething I might repent as long as I live—No, no, women and private ſoldiers ſhould beignorant.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: But prithee why wouldſt thou marry her, if ſhe be ugly, ill-bred, and ſilly? She muſt be rich then.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: As rich, as if ſhe had the wealth of the mogul—ſhe'll not ruin her huſband, like a London baggage, with a million of vices ſhe never heard of—then becauſe ſhe's ugly, ſhe's the likelier to be my own; and being ill-bred, ſhe'll hate converſation; and ſince ſilly and innocent, will not know the difference between me and you; that is, between a man of thirty, and one of forty.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Fifty, to my knowledge— [Moody turns off, and grumbles.] But ſee how you and I differ, Jack—wit to me is more neceſſary than beauty: I think no young woman ugly, that has it; and no handſome woman agreeable without it.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: 'Tis my maxim—He's a fool that marries; but he's a greater that does not marry a fool.—I know the town, Mr. Harcourt; and my wife ſhall be virtuous in ſpite of you or your nephew.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: My nephew!—poor ſheepiſh lad—he runs away from every woman he ſees—he ſaw your ſiſter Alithea at the opera, and was much ſmitten with her—He always toaſts her—and hates the very name of Sparkiſh; I'll bring him to your houſe—and you ſhall ſee what a formidable Tarquin he is.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: I have no curioſity, ſo give yourſelf no trouble.—You have heard of a wolf in ſheep's cloathing, and I have ſeen your innocent nephew kiſſing his hands at my windows.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: At your ſiſter, I ſuppoſe; nor at her unleſs he was tipſy—How can you, Jack, be ſo outragiouſly ſuſpicious? Sparkiſh has promis'd to introduce him to his miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Sparkiſh is a fool, and may be, what I'll take care not to be—I confeſs my viſit to you, Mr. Harcourt, was partly for old acquaintance ſake, but chiefly to deſire your nephew to confine his gallantries to the tavern, and not ſend 'em in looks, ſigns, or tokens, on the other ſide the way—I keep no brothel—ſo pray tell your nephew. [going.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Nay, prithee, Jack, leave me in better humour—Well, I'll tell him, ha, ha, ha! poor Dick, how he'll ſtare. This will give him a reputation, and the girls won't laugh at him any longer. Shall we dine together at the tavern, and ſend for my nephew to chide him for his gallantry? ha, ha, ha! we ſhall have fine ſport.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p:
I am not to be laught out of my ſenſes, Mr. Harcourt—I was once a modeſt, meek young gentleman myſelf, and I never have been half ſo miſchievous before or ſince, as I was in that ſtate of innocence—And ſo, old friend, make no ceremony with me—I have
much buſineſs, and you have much pleaſure, and therefore, as I hate forms, I will excuſe your returning my viſit; or ſending your nephew to ſatisfy me of his modeſty—and ſo your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: [alone.] Ha, ha, ha! poor Jack! what a life of ſuſpicion does he lead! I pity the poor fellow, tho' he ought, and will, ſuffer for his folly—Folly! 'tis treaſon, murder, ſacrilege! When perſons of a certain age will indulge their falſe, ungenerous appetites, at the expence of a young creature's happineſs, dame nature will revenge herſelf upon them for thwarting her moſt heavenly will and pleaſure.

head.hi: SCENE a Chamber in Moody's houſe.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: PRAY, ſiſter, where are the beſt fields and woods to walk in, in London?

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: A pretty queſtion! why, ſiſter, Vauxhall, Ranelagh, and St. James's Park, are the moſt frequented.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Pray, ſiſter, tell me why my Bud looks ſo grum here in town, and keeps me up cloſe, and will not let me go a walking, nor let me wear my beſt gown yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: O, he's jealous, ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Jealous! what's that?

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: He's afraid you ſhould love another man.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: How ſhould he be afraid of my loving another man, when he will not let me ſee any but himſelf?

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Did he not carry you yeſterday to a play?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Ay; but we ſat amongſt ugly people: he would not let me come near the gentry, who ſat under us, ſo that I could not ſee 'em. He told me none but naughty women ſat there—but I would have ventured for all that.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: But how did you like the play?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Indeed I was weary of the play; but I lik'd hugeouſly the actors; they are the goodlieſt, propereſt men, ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: O, but you muſt not like the actors, ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Ay, how ſhould I help it, ſiſter? Pray, ſiſter when my guardian comes in, will you aſk leave for me to go a walking?

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: A walking, ha, ha, ha! Lord a country gentlewoman's pleaſure is the drudgery of a footpoſt; and ſhe requires as much airing as her huſband's horſes. [aſide.
But here comes my brother, I'll aſk him, tho' I'm ſure he'll not grant it.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: O my dear, dear Bud, welcome home; why doſt thou look ſo ſropiſh? who has nanger'd thee?

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: You're a fool.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Faith, and ſo ſhe is, for crying for no fault—poor tender creature!

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: What, you would have her as impudent as yourſelf, as arrant a gilflirt, a gadder, a magpye, and, to ſay all, a mere notorious town-woman!

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Brother, you are my only cenſurer; and the honour of your family will ſooner ſuffer in your wife that is to be, than in me, tho' I take the innocent liberty of the town.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Hark you, Miſtreſs, do not talk ſo before my wife: the innocent liberty of the town!

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Pray, what ill people frequent my lodgings? I keep no company with any woman of ſcandalous reputation.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: No, you keep the men of ſcandalous reputation company.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Would you not have me civil, anſwer 'em at public places, walk with 'em when they join me in the Park, Ranelagh, or Vauxhall?

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Hold, hold; do not teach my wife where the men are to be found: I believe ſhe's the worſe for your town ducuments already. I bid you keep her in ignorance, as I do.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Indeed, be not angry with her, Bud, ſhe will tell me nothing of the town, tho' I aſk her a thouſand times a-day.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Then you are very inquiſitive to know, I find?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Not I, indeed, Dear; I hate London: our place-houſe in the country is worth a thouſand of't; would I were there again.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: So you ſhall, I warrant. But were you not talking of plays and players when I came in? you are her encourager in ſuch diſcourſes.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No, indeed, Dear, ſhe chid me juſt now for liking the player-men.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Nay, if ſhe is ſo innocent as to own to me her liking them, there is no hurt in't. [aſide.] Come, my poor Rogue, but thou likeſt none better than me?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes, indeed, but I do; the player-men are finer folks.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: But you love none better than me?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: You are my own dear Bud, and I know you; I hate ſtrangers.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Ay, my Dear, you muſt love me only; and not be like the naughty town-women, who only hate their huſbands, and love every man elſe, love plays, viſits, fine coaches, fine cloaths, fiddles, balls, treats, and ſo lead a wicked town-life.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Nay, if to enjoy all theſe things be a town-life, London is not ſo bad a place, Dear.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: How! if you love me, you muſt hate London.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: The fool has forbid me diſcovering to her the pleaſures of the town, and he is now ſetting her agog upon them himſelf. [aſide.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But, Bud, do the town-women love the player-men too?

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Yes, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Ay, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Why, you do not, I hope?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No, no, Bud; but why have we no player-men in the country?

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Ha! Mrs. Minx, aſk me no more to go to a play.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Nay, why, Love? I did not care for going: but when you forbid me, you make me as 'twere deſire 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: So 'twill be in other things, I warrant. [aſide.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Pray let me go to a play, Dear?

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Hold your peace, I won't.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Why, Love?

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Why, I'll tell you.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Nay, if he tell her, ſhe'll give him more cauſe to forbid her that place. [aſide.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Pray, why, Dear?

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Firſt, you like the actors; and the gallants may like you.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: What, a homely country girl? No, Bud, no body will like me.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: I tell you, yes, they may.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No, no, you jeſt—I won't believe you: I will go.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: I tell you then, that one of the moſt raking fellows in town, who ſaw you there, told me he was in love with you.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Indeed, who, who, pray, who was't?

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: I've gone too far, and ſlipt before I was aware. How overjov'd ſhe is. [aſide.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Was it any Hampſhire gallant, any of our neighbours?—Promiſe you, I am beholden to him.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: I promiſe you, you lye; for he wou'd but ruin you, as he has done hundreds.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Ay, but if he loves me, why ſhould he ruin me? anſwer me to that. Methinks he ſhou'd not; I wou'd do him no harm.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: 'Tis very well; but I'll keep him from doing you any harm, or me either. But here comes company, get you in, get you in.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But pray, huſband, is he a pretty gentleman, that loves me?

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: In, baggage, in. [thruſts her in, and ſhuts the door.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: What, all the libertines of the town brought to my lodging, by this eaſy coxcomb! 'Sdeath, I'll not ſuffer it.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Here, Belville, do you approve my choice? Dear little rogue, I told you, I'd bring you acquainted with all my friends, the wits.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Ay, they ſhall know her as well as you yourſelf will, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: This is one of thoſe, my pretty rogue, that are to dance at your wedding to morrow, and one you muſt make welcome, for he's modeſt. [Belville ſalutes Alithea.] Harcourt makes himſelf welcome, and has not the ſame foible, tho' of the ſame family.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: You are too obliging, Sparkiſh.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: And ſo he is indeed—the fop's horns will as naturally ſprout upon his brows, as muſhrooms upon dunghills.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: This, Mr. Moody, is my nephew you mentioned to me; I would bring him with me, for a ſight of him will be ſufficient, without poppy or mandragora, to reſtore you to your reſt.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: I am ſorry, Sir, that any miſtake, or imprudence of mine, ſhould have given you any uneaſineſs; it was not ſo intended, I aſſure you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: It may be ſo, Sir, but not the leſs criminal for that—My wife, Sir, muſt not be ſmirk'd and nodded at from tavern windows; I am a good ſhot, young gentleman, and don't ſuffer magpyes to come near my cherries.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Was it your wife, Sir?

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: What's that to you, Sir,—ſuppoſe it was my grandmother?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: I would not dare to offend her,—permit me to ſay a word in private to you.
sp.stage: [Moody and Belville retire out of ſight.]

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Now old ſurly is gone, tell me, Harcourt, if thou lik'ſt her as well as ever—My dear, don't look down, I ſhould hate to have a wife of mine out of countenance at any thing.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: For ſhame, Mr. Sparkiſh.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Tell me, I ſay, Harcourt, how doſt like her? thou haſt ſtar'd upon her enough to reſolve me.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: So infinitely well, that I could wiſh I had a miſtreſs too, that might differ from her in nothing but her love and engagement to you.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Sir, Mr. Sparkiſh has often told me, that his acquaintance were all wits and railers, and now I find it.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p:
No, by the univerſe, Madam, he does not rally now; you may believe him; I do aſſure you he is the honeſteſt, worthieſt, true-hearted gentleman;
a man of ſuch perfect honour, he would ſay nothing to a lady he does not mean.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Sir, you are ſo beyond expectation obliging, that—

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Nay, egad, I am ſure you do admire her extremely, I ſee it in your eyes.—He does admire you, Madam, he has told me ſo a thouſand and a thouſand times—have not you, Harcourt? You do admire her, by the world, you do—don't you?

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Yes, above the world, or the moſt glorious part of it, her whole ſex; and till now, I never thought I ſhould have envied you or any man about to marry: but you have the beſt excuſe to marry I ever knew.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Nay, now, Sir, I am ſatisfied you are of the ſociety of the wits, and railers ſince you cannot ſpare your friend, even when he is moſt civil to you; but the ſureſt ſign is, you are an enemy to marriage, the common butt of every railer.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Truly, Madam, I was never an enemy to marriage till now, becauſe marriage was never an enemy to me before.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: But why, Sir, is marriage an enemy to you now? becauſe it robs you of your friend here? for you look upon a friend married, as one gone into a monaſtery, that is dead to the world.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: 'Tis indeed, becauſe you marry him; I ſee, Madam, you can gueſs my meaning: I do confeſs heartily and openly, I wiſh it were in my power to break the match; by heavens, I wou'd.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Poor Frank!

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Wou'd you be ſo unkind to me?

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: No, no, 'tis not becauſe I wou'd be unkind to you.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Poor Frank, no, egad, 'tis only his kindneſs to me.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Great kindneſs to you, indeed—inſenſible! Let a man make love to his miſtreſs to his face. [aſide.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p:
Come, dear Frank, for all my wiſe there, that ſhall be, thou ſhalt enjoy me ſometimes, dear rogue: by my honour, we men of wit condole for our deceaſed brother in marriage, as much as for one dead
in earneſt: I think that was prettily ſaid of me, ha, Harcourt?—But come, Frank, be not melancholy for me.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: No, I aſſure you, I am not melancholy for you.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Prithee, Frank, do'ſt think my wife, that ſhall be, there, a fine perſon?

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: I cou'd gaze upon her, till I became as blind as you are.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: How, as I am? how?

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Becauſe you are a lover, and true lovers are blind, ſtock blind.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: True, true; but, by the world, ſhe has wit too, as well as beauty: go, go with her into a corner, and try if ſhe has wit; talk to her any thing, ſhe's baſhful before me.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Sir, you diſpoſe of me a little before your time. [aſide to Sparkiſh.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Madam, let me have an earneſt of your obedience, or—go, go, Madam.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: How, Sir, if you are not concern'd for the honour of a wife, I am for that of a ſiſter; be a pander to your own wife, bring men to her, let e'm make love before your face, huſt 'em into a corner together, then leave 'em in private! is this your town wit and conduct?

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! a ſilly wiſe rogue wou'd make one laugh more than a ſtark fool, ha, ha, ha! I ſhall burſt. Nay, you ſhall not diſturb'em; I'll vex thee, by the world. What have you done with Belville?
sp.stage: [Struggles with Moody to keep him from Harcourt and Alithea.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Shewn him the way out of my houſe, as you ſhould to that gentleman.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Nay, but prithee—let me reaſon with thee.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: The writings are drawn, Sir, ſettlements made, 'tis too late, Sir, and paſt all revocation.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Them ſo is my death.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: I wou'd not be unjuſt to him.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Then why to me ſo?

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: I have no obligation to you.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: My love.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: I had his before.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: You never had it; he wants, you ſee, jealouſy, the only infallible ſign of it.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Love proceeds from eſteem; he cannot diſtruſt my virtue; beſides, he loves me, or he would not marry me.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Marrying you, is no more a ſign of his lo ve, than bribing your woman, that he may marry you, is a ſign of his generoſity. But if you take marriage for a ſign of lo ve, take it from me immediately.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: No, now you have put a ſcruple in my head; but in ſhort, Sir, to end our diſpute, I muſt marry him; my reputation wou'd ſuffer in the world elſe.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: No; if you do marry him, with your pardon, Madam, your reputation ſuffers in the world.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Nay, now you are rude, Sir—Mr. Sparkiſh, pray come hither, your friend here is very troubleſome, and very loving.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Hold, hold. [aſide to Alithea.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: D'ye hear that;—ſenſeleſs puppy!

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Why, d'ye think I'll ſeem jealous, like a country bumkin?

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: No, rather be diſhonour'd like a credulous driv'ler.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Madam, you would not have been ſo little generous as to have told him?

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Yes, ſince you could be ſo little generous as to wrong him.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Wrong him, no man can do't, he's beneath an injury; a bubble, a coward, a ſenſeleſs idiot, a wretch ſo contemptible to all the world but you, that—

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Hold, do not rail at him, for ſince he is like to be my huſband, I am reſolv'd to like him: nay, I think I am oblig'd to tell him, you are not his friend—Mr. Sparkiſh, Mr. Sparkiſh!

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: What, what; now, dear rogue, has not ſhe wit?

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Not ſo much as I thought, and hoped ſhe had. [ſurlily.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Mr. Sparkiſh, do you bring people to rail at you?

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: How! no; but if he does rail at me, 'tis but in jeſt, I warrant: what we wits do for one another, and never take any notice of it.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: He ſpoke ſo ſcurrilouſly of you, I had no patience to hear him.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: And he was in the right on't.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Beſides, he has been making love to me.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: And I told the fool ſo—

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: True, damn'd tell-tale woman. [aſide.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Pſhaw, to ſhew his parts—We wits rail and make love often, but to ſhew our parts; as we have no affections, ſo we have no malice, we—

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Did you ever hear ſuch an aſs!

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: He ſaid you were a wretch below an injury.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Pſhaw.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: A common bubble.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Pſhaw.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: A coward!

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Pſhaw, pſhaw!

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: A ſenſeleſs drivelling idiot.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: True, true, true; all true.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: How! did he diſparage my parts? nay, then my honour's concern'd. I can't put up that, Sir; by the world, brother, help me to kill him. [offers to draw.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: What, what?

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: I muſt not let 'em kill the gentleman neither. [aſide.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: I'll be thy death. [putting up his ſword.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: If Harcourt would but kill Sparkiſh, and run away with my ſiſter, I ſhou'd be rid of three plagues at once.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Hold, hold; indeed, to tell the truth, the gentleman ſaid, after all, that what he ſpoke, was but out of friendſhip to you.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: How! ſay, I am a fool, that is, no wit, out of friendſhip to me?

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p:
Yes, to try whether I was concern'd enough
for you; and made love to me only to be ſatisfy'd of my virtue, for your ſake.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Kind, however. [aſide.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Nay, if it were ſo, my dear rogue, I aſk thee pardon; but why wou'd not you tell me ſo, faith?

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Becauſe I did not think on't, faith!

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Come, Belville is gone away; Harcourt, let's be gone to the new play—Come, Madam.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: I will not go, if you intend to leave me alone in the box, and run all about the houſe as you uſe to do.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Pſhaw, I'll leave Harcourt with you in the box, to entertain you, and that's as good; if I ſat in the box, I ſhou'd be thought no critick—I muſt run about, my dear, and abuſe the author—Come away, Harcourt, lead her down. B'ye, brother.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: B'ye, driv'ler; well, go thy ways, for the flower of the true town fops, ſuch as ſpend their eſtates before they come to 'em, and are cuckolds before they're married. But let me go look to my free-hold.
Maſter, your worſhip's ſervant—here is the lawyer, counſeller gentleman, with a green bag full of papers, come again, and would be glad to ſpeak to you.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Now, here's ſome other damn'd impediment, which the law has thrown in our way—I ſhall never marry the girl, nor get clear of the ſmoke and wickedneſs of this curſed town; where is he?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: He's below in a coach, with three other lawyer, counſeller gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What ails you, Miſs Peggy? you are grown quite melancholy.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Would it not make any one melancholy to ſee your miſtreſs Alithea go every day fluttering about abroad to plays and aſſemblies, and I know not what, whilſt I muſt ſtay at home, like a poor lonely ſullen bird in a cage?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Dear Miſs Peggy, I thought you choſe to be confin'd: I imagin'd that you had been bred ſo young to the cage, that you had no pleaſure in flying about, and hopping in the open air, as other young ladies who go a little wild about this town.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Nay, I confeſs, I was quiet enough, 'till ſomebody told me what pure lives the London ladies lead, with their dancing meetings, and junketings, and dreſs'd every day in their beſt gowns; and I warrant you play at nine-pins every day in the week, ſo they do.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: To be ſure, Miſs, you will lead a better life when join'd in holy wedlock with your ſweet temper'd guardian, the chearful Mr. Moody.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I can't lead a worſe, that's one good thing—but I muſt make the beſt of a bad market, for I can't marry nobody elſe.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: How ſo, Miſs? that's very ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Why we have a contraction to one another—ſo we are as good as married, you know—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I know it! Heav'n forbid, Miſs—

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Heigho!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Don't ſigh, Miſs Peggy—if that young gentleman, who was here juſt now, would take pity on me, I'd throw ſuch a contract as yours behind the fire.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Lord bleſs us, how you talk!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Young Mr. Belville would make you talk otherwiſe, if you knew him.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Mr. Belville!—where is he?—when did you ſee him?—you have undone me, Lucy—where was he? did he ſay any thing?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Say any thing! very little, indeed—he's quite diſtracted, poor young creature. He was talking with your guardian juſt now.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: The duce he was! but where was it, and when was it?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: In this houſe, five minutes ago, when your guardian turn'd you into your chamber, for fear of your being ſeen.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I knew ſomething was the matter, I was in ſuch a ſluſter—but what did he ſay to my Bud?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What do you call him Bud for? Bud means huſband, and he is not your huſband yet—and I hope never will be—and if he was my huſband, I'd bud him, a ſurly unreaſonable beaſt.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I'd call him any names, to keep him in good humour—if he'd let me marry any body elſe (which I can't do) I'd call him huſband as long as he liv'd—But what ſaid Mr. Belville to him?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I don't know what he ſaid to him, but I'll tell you what he ſaid to me, with a ſigh, and his hand upon his breaſt as he went out of the door—If you ever were in love, young gentlewoman, (meaning me) and can pity a moſt faithful lover—tell the dear object of my affections—

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Meaning me, Lucy?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, you, to be ſure. Tell the dear object of my affections, I live but upon the hopes that ſhe is not married; and when thoſe hopes leave me—ſhe knows the reſt—then he caſt up his eyes thus—gnaſh'd his teeth—ſtruck his forehead—would have ſpoke again, but could not—fetch'd a deep ſigh, and vaniſh'd.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: That is really very fine—I'm ſure it makes my heart ſink within me, and brings tears into my eyes—O he's a charming ſweet—but huſh, huſh, I hear my huſband!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Don't call him huſband. Go into the Park this evening, if you can.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Mum, mum—

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Come, what's here to do? you are putting the town pleaſures in her head, and ſetting her a longing.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, after nine-pins: you ſuffer none to give her thoſe longings you mean, but yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Come, Mrs. Elippant, good precepts are loſt when bad examples are ſtill before us: the liberty your miſtreſs takes abroad makes her hanker after it, and out of humour at home: poor wretch! ſhe deſired not to come to London; I would bring her.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: O yes, you ſurfeit her with pleaſures.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: She has been this fortnight in town, and never deſired, till this afternoon, to go abroad.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Was ſhe not at the play yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Yes; but ſhe ne'er aſk'd me: I was myſelf the cauſe of her going.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Then if ſhe aſk you again, you are the cauſe of her aſking, and not my miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Well, next week I ſhall be rid of you all, rid of this town, and my dreadful apprehenſions. Come, be not melancholy, for thou ſhalt go into the country very ſoon, deareſt.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Great comfort!

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Piſh, what d'ye tell me of the country for.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: How's this! what, piſh at the country?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Let me alone, I am not well.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: O, if that be all,—what ails my deareſt?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Truly, I don't know; but I have not been well ſince you told me there was a gallant at the play in love with me.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: That's my miſtreſs too.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Nay, if you are not well, but are ſo concern'd, becauſe a raking fellow chanced to lye, and ſay he lik'd you, you'll make me ſick too.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Of what ſickneſs?

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: O, of that which is worſe than the plague, jealouſy.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Piſh, you jeer: I'm ſure there's no ſuch diſeaſe in our receipt book at home.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: No, thou never met'ſt with it, poor innocent.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Well, but pray, Bud, let's go to a play tonight.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: No, no;—no more plays—But why are you ſo eager to ſee a play?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Faith, Dear, not that I care one pin for their talk there; but I like to look upon the player-men, and wou'd ſee, if I could, the gallant you ſay loves me: that's all, dear Bud.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Is that all, dear Bud?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: This proceeds from my miſtreſs's example.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Let's go abroad however, dear Bud, if we do't go to the play.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Come, have a little patience, and thou ſhalt go into the country next week.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Therefore I would ſee firſt ſome ſights, to tell my neighbours of: nay, I will go abroad, that's once.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: What, you have put this into her head?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Heav'n defend me, what ſuſpicions! ſomebody has put more things into your head than you ought to have.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Your tongue runs too glibly, Madam, and you have liv'd too long with a London lady, to be a proper companion for innocence—I am not overfond of you, miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: There's no love loſt between us.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: You admitted thoſe gentlemen into the houſe, when I ſaid I wou'd not be at home; and there was the young fellow too that behav'd ſo indecently to my wife at the tavern window.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Becauſe you wou'd not let him ſee your handſome wife out of your lodgings.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Why, O Lord! did the gentleman come hither to ſee me indeed?

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: No, no, you are not the cauſe of that damn'd queſtion too.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Come, pray, Bud, let's go abroad before 'tis late; for I will go, that's flat and plain—only into the Park.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: So! the obſtinacy already of the town-wife; and I muſt, whilſt ſhe's here, humour her like one. [Aſide.] How ſhall we do, that ſhe may not be ſeen or known?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Muffle her up with a bonnet and handkerchief, and I'll go with her to avoid ſuſpicion.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: And run into more danger.—No, no, I am obliged to you for your kindneſs, but ſhe ſhan't ſtir without me.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What will you do then?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: What, ſhall we go? I am ſick with ſtaying at home: if I don't walk in the Park, I'll do nothing that I am bid for a week—I won't be mop'd.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: O, ſhe has a charming ſpirit! I could ſtand your friend now, and would, if you had ever a civil word to give me.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: I'll give thee a better thing, I'll give thee a guinea for thy good advice, if I like it; and I can have the beſt of the ollege for the ſame money.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I deſpiſe a bribe—when I am your friend, it ſhall be without fee or reward.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Don't be long then, for I will go out.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: The taylor brought home laſt night the clothes you intend for a preſent to your godſon in the country.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: You muſt not tell that, Lucy.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But I will, Madam—When you were with your lawyers laſt night, Miſs Peggy, to divert me and herſelf, put 'em on, and they fitted her to a hair.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Thank you, thank you, Lucy—'tis the luckieſt thought! Go this moment, Peggy, into your chamber, and put 'em on again—and you ſhall walk with me into the Park, as my godſon—Well thought of, Lucy—I ſhall love you for ever for this.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: And ſo ſhall I too, Lucy, I'll put 'em on directly. [going, returns.] Suppoſe, Bud, I muſt keep on my petticoats, for fear of ſhewing my legs?

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: No, no, you fool, never mind your legs.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No more I will then, Bud—This is pure.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: What a ſimpleton it is! Well, Lucy, I thank you for the thought, and before I leave London, thou ſhalt be convinc'd how much I am obliged to thee.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: And before you leave London, Mr. Moody, I hope I ſhall convince you how much you are oblig'd to me.

div.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: AND the moment Moody left me, and before I left his lodgings, I took an opportunity of conveying ſome tender ſentiments thro' Lucy to Miſs Peggy, and it was Lucy advis'd me to ſtrole here this evening; and here I am in expectation of ſeeing my country goddeſs.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: And ſo to blind Moody, and take him off the ſcent of your paſſion for this girl, and at the ſame time to give me an opportunity with Sparkiſh's miſtreſs, (and of which I have made the moſt) you hinted to him with a grave melancholy face, that you were dying for his ſiſter—gad-a-mercy, nephew! I will back thy modeſty againſt any other in the three kingdoms—It will do, Dick.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: What could I do, uncle?—it was my laſt ſtake, and I play'd for a great deal.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: You miſtake me, Dick, I don't ſay you could do better—I only can't account for your modeſty's doing ſo much; you have done ſuch wonders, that I, who am rather bold than ſheepiſh, have not yet ceas'd wondering at you. But do you think that you impos'd upon him?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Faith, I can't ſay—I am rather doubtful, he ſaid very little, grumbled much, ſhook his head, and ſhew'd me the door.—But what ſucceſs have you had with Alithea?

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Juſt enough to have a glimmering of hope, without having light enough to ſee an inch before my noſe.—This day will produce ſomething; Alithea is a woman of great honour, and will ſacrifice her happineſs to it, unleſs Sparkiſh's abſurdity ſtand my friend, and does every thing that the fates ought to do for me.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Yonder comes the prince of coxcombs, and if your miſtreſs and mine ſhould, by chance, be tripping this way, this fellow will ſpoil ſport—let us avoid him—you can't cheat him before his face.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: But I can tho', thanks to my wit, and his want of it; a fooliſh rival, and a jealous huſband, aſſiſt their rivals deſigns, for they are ſure to make their women hate them, which is their firſt ſtep to their love for another man.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: But you cannot come near his miſtreſs but in his company.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Still the better for me, nephew, for fools are moſt eaſily cheated, when they themſelves are acceſſaries, and he is to be bubbled of his miſtreſs, or of his money (the common miſtreſs) by keeping him company.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Who's that is to be bubbled? faith, let me ſnack; I han't met with a bubble ſince Chriſtmas. 'Gad, I think bubbles are like their brother woodcocks, go out with the cold weather.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: O pox, he did not hear all, I hope?[apart to Belville.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Come, you bubbling rogues you, where do we ſup? O Harcourt, my miſtreſs tells me, you have made love, fierce love to her laſt night, all the play long, ha, ha, ha! but I—

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: I make love to her!

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Nay, I forgive thee, and I know her, but I am ſure I know myſelf.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Do you, Sir? Then you are the wiſeſt man in the world, and I honour you as ſuch. [bowing.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: O, your ſervant, Sir, you are at your raillery, are you?—You can't oblige me more—I'm your man—He'll meet with his match—Ha! Harcourt!—Did not you hear me laugh prodigiouſly at the play laſt night?

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Yes, and was very much diſturb'd at it.—You put the actors and audience into confuſion—and all your friends out of countenance.

sp.speaker: Spark:
sp.p: So much the better—I love confuſion—and to ſee folks out of countenance;—I was in tip top ſpirits, faith, and ſaid a thouſand good things.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: But I thought you had gone to plays to laugh at the poet's good things, and not at your own?

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Your ſervant, Sir: no, I thank you. 'Gad I go to a play, as to a country treat: I carry my own wine to one, and my own wit to t'other, or elſe I'm ſure I ſhould not be merry at either: and the reaſon why we are ſo often louder than the players, is, becauſe we hate authors damnably.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: But why ſhould you hate the poor rogues? you have too much wit, and deſpiſe writing, I'm fure.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: O yes, I deſpiſe writing. But women! women, that make men do all fooliſh things, make 'em write ſongs too. Every body does it: 'Tis e'en as common with lovers, as playing with fans; and you can no more help rhyming to your Phillis, than drinking to your Phillis.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: But the poets damn'd your ſongs, did they?

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: O yes, damn the poets; they turn'd them into burleſque, as they call it: That burleſque is a hocus pocus trick they have got, which by the virtue of hictius doctius, topſey turvey, they make a clever witty thing abſolute nonſenſe; do you know, Harcourt, that they ridicul'd my laſt ſong, twang, twang, the beſt I ever wrote?

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: That may be, and be very eaſily ridicul'd for all that.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Favour me with it, Sir, I never heard it.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: What, and have all the Park about us?

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Which you'll not diſlike, and ſo prithee begin.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: I never am aſk'd twice—and ſo have at you.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: Tell not me of the roſes, and lilies,
Which tinge the fair cheek of your Phillis,
Tell not me of the dimples, and eyes,
For which ſilly Corydon dies;
Let all whining lovers go hang,
My heart would you hit,
Tip your arrow with wit,
And it comes to my heart with a twang, twang,
And it comes to my heart with a twang.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: I am rock to the handſome, and pretty,
Can only be touch'd by the witty;
And beauty will ogle in vain,
The way to my heart's thro' my brain.
Let all whining lovers go hang,
We wits, you muſt know,
Have two ſtrings to our bow,
To return them their darts with a twang, twang,
And return them their darts with a twang.

div.stage: At the end of the ſong Harcourt and Belville ſteal away from Sparkiſh, and leave him ſinging—He ſinks his voice by degrees at the ſurpriſe of their being gone; then

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: What the deuce did you go away for?

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Your miſtreſs is coming.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: The devil ſhe is—O hide, hide me from her. [hides behind Harcourt.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: She ſees you.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: But I will not ſee her: for I'm engag'd, and at this inſtant. [looking at his watch.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Pray firſt take me, and reconcile me to her.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Another time: faith, it is to a lady, and one cannot make excuſes to a woman.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: You have need of 'em I believe.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Pſhaw, prithee hide me.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Your ſervant, Mr. Moody.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Come along— [to Peggy.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Lau!—what a ſweet delightful place this is!

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Come along, I ſay—don't ſtare about you ſo—you'll betray yourſelf—

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: He does not know us—

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Or he won't know us—

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: So much the better—
sp.stage: [Exit. Belville after them at a diſtance.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Who is that pretty youth with him, Sparkiſh?

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Some relation of Peggy's, I ſuppoſe, for he is ſomething like her in face and gawkyneſs.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: By all my hopes, uncle—Peggy in man's clothes—I am all over agitation. [aſide to Harc.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Be quiet, or you'll ſpoil all. They return—Alithea has ſeen you, Sparkiſh, and will be angry if you don't go to her: beſides, I wou'd fain be reconcil'd to her, which none but you can do, my dear friend.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Well, that's a better reaſon, dear friend: I wou'd not go near her now for her's or my own ſake; but I can deny you nothing: for tho' I have known thee a great while, never go, if I do not love thee as well as a new acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: I am obliged to you indeed, my dear friend: I wou'd be well with her, only to be well with thee ſtill; for theſe ties to wives uſually diſſolve all ties to friends.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: But they ſhan't tho'—come along.

div.stage: Re-enter Moody and Peggy in man's clothes, Alithea following.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Siſter, if you will not go, we muſt leave you— [to Alithea.] The fool her gallant and ſhe will muſter up all the young ſaunterers of this place. what a ſwarm of cuckolds and cuckold-makers are here? I begin to be uneaſy. [aſide.] Come, let's be gone, Peggy.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Don't you believe that I han't half my bellyful of ſights yet?

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Then walk this way.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Lord, what a power of fine folks are here. And Mr. Belville, as I hope to be married. [aſide.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Come along; what are you a muttering at?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: There's the young gentleman there, you were ſo angry about—that's in love with me.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: No, no, he's a dangler after your ſiſter—or pretends to be—but they are all bad alike—come along, I ſay. [he pulls her away.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I'm glad to hear that—perhaps I may fit you tho'.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Come, dear Madam, for my ſake you ſhall be reconciled to him.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: For your ſake I hate him.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: That's ſomething too cruel, Madam, to hate me, for his ſake.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Ay, indeed, Madam, too, too cruel to me, to hate my friend for my ſake.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: I hate him, becauſe he is your enemy; and you ought to hate him too, for making love to me, if you love me.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: That's a good one! I hate a man for loving you! If he did love you, 'tis but what he can't help; and 'tis your fault, not his, if he admires you.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Is it for your honour, or mine, to ſuffer a man to make love to me, who am to marry you tomorrow?

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: But, why, deareſt Madam, will you be more concern'd for his honour than he is himſelf? Let his honour alone for my ſake and his. He has no honour.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: But what, my dear friend, can guard himſelf.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: O ho—that's right again.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: You aſtoniſh me, Sir, with want of jealouſy.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: And you make me giddy, Madam, with your jealouſy and fears, and virtue and honour: 'Gad, I ſee virtue makes a woman as troubleſome as a little reading or learning.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Come, Madam, you ſee you ſtrive in vain to make him jealous of me: my dear friend is the kindeſt creature in the world to me.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Poor fellow.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: But his kindneſs only is not enough for me, without your favour, your good opinion, dear Madam: 'tis that muſt perfect my happineſs. Good gentleman, he believes all I ſay: wou'd you wou'd do ſo. Jealous of me! I wou'd not wrong him nor you for the world.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Look you there: hear him, hear him, and not walk away ſo. Come back again.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: I love you, Madam, ſo—

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: How's that! nay—now you begin to go too far indeed.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: So much, I confeſs, I ſay, I love you, that I wou'd not have you miſerable, and caſt yourſelf away upon ſo unworthy and inconſiderable a thing, as what you ſee here.
sp.stage: [Clapping his hand on his breaſt, points to Sparkiſh.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: No, faith, I believe thou wou'dſt not; now his meaning is plain; but I knew before thou wou'dſt not wrong me, nor her.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p:
No, no, heav'ns forbid the glory of her ſex ſhou'd fall ſo low, as into the embraces of ſuch a contemptible
temptible wretch, the leaſt of mankind—my dear friend here—I injure him. [embracing Sparkiſh.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: No, no, dear friend, I knew it: Madam, you ſee he will rather wrong himſelf than me in giving himſelf ſuch names.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Do not you underſtand him yet?

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Come, come, you ſhall ſtay till he has ſaluted you; that I may be aſſur'd you are friends, after his honeſt advice and declaration: come, pray, Madam, be friends with him.

div.stage: Enter Moody and Peggy. Belville at a diſtance.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: You muſt pardon me, Sir, that I am not yet ſo obedient to you.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: What, invite your wife to kiſs men? Monſtrous! Are you not aſham'd? I will never forgive you. Let's be gone, ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: Are you not aſham'd, that I ſhou'd have more confidence in the chaſtity of your family, than you have?—You muſt not teach me, I am a man of honour, Sir, tho' I am frank and free; I am frank, Sir—

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Very frank, Sir, to ſhare your wife with your friends—You ſeem to be angry and yet won't go. [to Alithea.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: No impertinence ſhall drive me away.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Becauſe you like it—But you ought to bluſh at expoſing your wife as you do.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: What then? It may be I have a pleaſure in't, as I have to ſhew fine clothes at a play-houſe, the firſt day, and count money before poor rogues.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: He that ſhews his wife, or money, will be in danger of having them borrowed ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Spark.
sp.p: I love to be envy'd, and wou'd not marry a wife, that I alone cou'd love. Loving alone is as dull as eating alone; and ſo good night, for I muſt to Whitehall—Madam, I hope, you are now reconcil'd to my friend; and ſo I wiſh you a good night, Madam, and ſleep if you can; for to-morrow you know I muſt viſit you early with a canonical gentleman. Good night, dear Harcourt—remember to ſend your brother.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: You may depend upon me. Madam, I hope you will not refuſe my viſit to-morrow, if it ſhould be earlier, with a canonical gentleman, than Mr. Sparkiſh.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: This gentlewoman is yet under my care, therefore you muſt yet forbear your freedom with her. [coming between Alithea and Harcourt.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Muſt, Sir!

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, ſhe is my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: 'Tis well ſhe is, Sir—for I muſt be her ſervant, Sir.—Madam—

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Come away, ſiſter, we had been gone if it had not been for you, and ſo avoided theſe lewd rakehells, who ſeem to haunt us.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: I ſee a little time in the country makes a man turn wild and unſociable, and only fit to converſe with his horſes, dogs, and his herds.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: I have buſineſs, Sir, and muſt mind it: your buſineſs is pleaſure, therefore you and I muſt go diff'rent ways.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Well, you may go on; but this pretty young gentleman [takes hold of Peggy] ſhall ſtay with us, for I ſuppoſe his buſineſs is the ſame with ours, pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, he knows her, ſhe carries it ſo ſillily; yet if he does not, I ſhou'd be more ſilly to diſcover it firſt [aſide.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Pray let him go, Sir.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Come, come.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Had you not rather ſtay with us? [to Peggy.] Prithee who is this pretty young fellow?

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: One to whom I am a guardian—I wiſh I cou'd keep her out of your hands. [aſide.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Who is he? I never ſaw any thing ſo pretty in all my life.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Pſhaw, do not look upon him ſo much, he's a poor baſhful youth, you'll put him out of countenance. [offers to take her away.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Here, nephew—let me introduce this young gentleman to your acquaintance—You are very like, and of the ſame age, and ſhould know one another—Salute him, Dick, a la Francoiſe.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: I hate French faſhions. Men kiſs one another. [Endeavours to take hold of her.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I am out of my wits—What do you kiſs me for, I am no woman.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: But you are ten times handſomer.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Nay, now you jeer one; and pray don't jeer me.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Kiſs him again, Dick.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: No, no, no; come away, come away. [to Peggy.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Why, what haſte are you in? Why won't you let me talk with him?

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Becauſe you'll debauch him, he's yet young and innocent. How ſhe gazes upon him! The devil! [aſide.] Come, pray let him go, I cannot ſtay fooling any longer; I tell you my wife ſtays ſupper for us.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Does ſhe? Come then, we'll all go ſup with her.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: No, no—now I think on't, having ſtaid ſo long for us, I warrant ſhe's gone to bed—I wiſh ſhe and I were well out of your hands. [aſide.] Come, I muſt riſe early to-morrow; come—

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Well then, if ſhe be gone to bed, I wiſh her and you a good night. But pray, young gentleman, preſent my humble ſervice to her.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Thank you heartily, Sir. [bowing.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, ſhe will diſcover herſelf yet in ſpite of me. [aſide.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: And mine too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: That I will, indeed. [bowing.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Pray give her this kiſs for me. [kiſſes Peggy.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: O heavens! what do I ſuffer?

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: And this for me.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Thank you, Sir. [courtſies.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: O the idiot—now 'tis out—Ten thouſand cankers gnaw away their lips. Come, come, Driv'ler.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Good night, dear little gentleman. Madam, good night—Farewel, Moody—Come, nephew—have not I rais'd his jealous gall finely?[aſide to Belville.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: A little too much I fear.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: So, they are gone at laſt. Siſter, ſtay with Peggy—'till I find my ſervant—don't let her ſtir an inch, I'll be back directly. [Exit Moody.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: What, not gone yet?—Nephew, ſhew the young gentleman Roſamond's Pond, while I ſpeak another word to this lady.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Shall I have that pleaſure?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: With all my heart and ſoul, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: I cannot conſent to it indeed.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Let 'em look upon the place where ſo many deſpairing lovers have been deſtroy'd—You muſt indulge them—and me too in a few words.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: My brother will go diſtracted—tho' he deſerves to be vex'd a little for his brutality.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: My nephew is a very modeſt young man, you may depend upon his prudence.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Modeſt, prudent, and your nephew—I can't believe it, and I muſt follow them.— [going.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Where! How!—what's become of—gone—whither?—

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: He's only gone with the young gentleman to ſee ſomething.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Something! ſee ſomething! with a plague—where are they?

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: In the next walk only, brother.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Only, only, where, where?—

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: What's the matter with him? Why ſo much concerned? But, deareſt Madam—

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Pray let me go, Sir; I have ſaid and ſuffered enough already.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.p: Then you will not look upon, nor pity my ſufferings?

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: To look upon 'em, when I cannot help 'em, were cruelty, not pity; therefore I will never ſee you more.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Gone, gone, not to be found; quite gone; ten thouſand plagues go with 'em; which way went they?

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: But in t'other walk, brother.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: T'other walk—t'other devil! You are ſo full of vanity, and fond of admiration, that you'll ſuffer your own honour and mine to run any riſque, rather than not indulge your inordinate deſire of flattery.—Where are they, I ſay?

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: You are too abuſive, brother, and too violent about trifles; therefore let your jealouſy ſearch for them, for I know nothing of 'em.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: You know where they are, you infamous wretch, eternal ſhame of your family; which you do not diſhonour enough yourſelf, you think, but you muſt help her to it too, thou legion of—

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Good brother—

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: Falſe, falſe ſiſter—

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Shew me to my chair, Mr. Harcourt—His ſcurrility has overpower'd me—I will get rid of his tyranny and your importunities, and give my hand to Sparkiſh to-morrow morning.

head.hi: SCENE changes to another part of the Park.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: No diſguiſe could conceal you from my heart; I pretended not to know you, that I might deceive the dragon that continually watches over you—but now he's aſleep, let us fly from miſery to happineſs.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Indeed, Mr. Belville, as well as I like you, I can't think of going away with you ſo—and as much as I hate my guardian, I muſt take leave of him a little handſomely, or he will kill me, ſo he will.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p:
But, dear Miſs Peggy, think of your ſituation;
if we don't make the beſt uſe of this opportunity, we never may have another.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Ay, but Mr. Belville—I am as good as married already—my guardian has contracted me, and there wants nothing but church ceremony to make us one—I call him huſband, and he calls me wife already: He made me do ſo;—and we had been married in church long ago, if the writings could have been finiſhed.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: That's his deceit, my ſweet creature—He pretends to have married you, for fear of your liking any body elſe—You have a right to chuſe for yourſelf, and there is no law in heaven or earth that binds you before marriage to a man you cannot like.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I'fack, no more I believe it does; ſiſter Alithea's maid has told me as much—ſhe's a very ſenſible girl.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: You are in the very jaws of perdition, and nothing but running away can avoid it—the law will finiſh your chains to-morrow, and the church will rivet them the day after—Let us ſecure our happineſs by eſcape, and love and fortune will do the reſt for us.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Theſe are fine ſayings, to be ſure, Mr. Belville; but how ſhall we get my fortune out of Bud's clutches? We muſt be a little cunning, 'tis worth trying for—We can at any time run away without it.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: I ſee by your fears, my dear Peggy, that you live in awe of this brutal guardian; and if he has you once more in his poſſeſſion, both you and your fortune are ſecur'd to him for ever.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Ay, but it ſhan't, tho'—I thank him for that.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: If you marry without his conſent, he can but ſeize upon half your fortune—The other half, and a younger brother's fortune, with a treaſure of love, are our own—Take it, my ſweeteſt Peggy, and this moment, or we ſhall be divided for ever. [kneels and preſſes 〈◊〉 hand.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Ifackins, but we won't—Your fine talk has bewitch'd me.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: 'Tis you have bewitch'd me—thou dear inchanting ſweet ſimplicity—Let us fly with the wings of love to my houſe there, and we ſhall be ſafe for ever.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: And ſo we will then—there ſqueeze me again by the hand; now run away with me, and if my guardy follows us, the devil take the hindmoſt, I ſay. [going] Boo!—here he is.

div.stage: Enter Moody haſtily, and meets them.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Curſt fortune!

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: O! there's my ſtray'd ſheep, and the wolf again in ſheep's cloathing!—Now I have recover'd her, I ſhall come to my ſenſes again—Where have you been, you puppy?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Been, Bud?—We have been hunting all over the Park to find you.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: From one end to the other, Sir. [confuſedly.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: But not where I was to be found, you young devil you—Why did you ſtart when you ſaw me?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I'm always frighten'd when I ſee you, and if I did not love you ſo well—I ſhould run away from you, ſo I ſhould. [pouting.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: But I'll take care you don't.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: This gentleman has a favour to beg of you, Bud.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: I am not in the humour to grant favours to young gentlemen, tho' you may.—What have you been doing with this young lady?—Gentleman I would ſay,—bliſters on my tongue!

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Fie, Bud, you have told all.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: I have been as civil as I could to the young ſtranger; and if you'll permit me, I will take the trouble off your hands, and ſhew the young ſpark Roſamond's Pond, for he has not ſeen it yet—Come, pretty youth, will you go with me?[goes to her.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: As my guardian pleaſes.

sp.speaker: Moody.
sp.p: No, no, it does not pleaſe me—whatever I think he ought to ſee, I ſhall ſhow him myſelf—You may viſit Roſamond's Pond if you will—and the bottom of it, if you will—And ſo, Sir, your humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: What curſed luck! [ſtamps] to be prevented at the very inſtant of my carrying off the golden fleece!—We have now rais'd his ſuſpicions to ſuch a degree, that he'll lock her up directly—ſign articles this night—marry her in the morning—and away from the church into the country.—What a miſerable ſituation am I in!—I have love enough to be a knighterrant in the cauſe—I will loſe my life, or reſcue my Dulcinea.—I have hopes in her ſpirit too—for at the worſt ſhe can open her window, throw herſelf into my arms, from thence into a poſt-chaiſe, and away for the Tweed as faſt as love and four poſt-horſes can carry us.

div.trailer: The END of the THIRD ACT.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: WELL, Madam, now I have dreſs'd you, and ſet you out with ſo many ornaments, and ſpent ſo much time upon you, and all this for no other purpoſe but to bury you alive; for I look upon Mr. Sparkiſh's bed to be little better than a grave.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, I will aſk you the reaſon, why you would baniſh poor Mr. Harcourt for ever from your ſight? how cou'd you be ſo hard-hearted?

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: 'Twas becauſe I was not hard-hearted.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No, no; 'twas ſtark love and kindneſs, I warrant?

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: It was ſo: I would ſee him no more becauſe I love him.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Hey day! a very pretty reaſon.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: You do not underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I wiſh you may yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: I was engag'd to marry, you ſee, another man, whom my juſtice will not ſuffer me to deceive or injure.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Can there be a greater cheat or wrong done to a man, than to give him your perſon, without your heart? I ſhould make a conſcience of it.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: I'll retrieve it for him, after I am married.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: The woman that marries to love better, will be as much miſtaken, as the rake that marries to live better.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: What nonſenſe you talk.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: 'Tis a melancholy truth, Madam—Marrying to increaſe love, is like gaming to become rich—Alas! you only loſe what little ſtock you had before—There are many woeful examples of it in this righteous town!

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: I find by your rhetorick you have been brib'd to betray me.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Only by his merit, that has brib'd your heart, you ſee, againſt your word and rigid honour.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Come, pray talk no more of honour, nor Mr. Harcourt; I wiſh the other wou'd come to ſecure my fidelity to him, and his right in me.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You will marry him then?

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Certainly; I have given him already my word, and will my hand too, to make it good, when he comes.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well, I wiſh I may never ſtick a pin more, if he be not an errant natural to t'other fine gentleman.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: I own he wants the wit of Harcourt, which I will diſpenſe withal, for another want he has, which is want of jealouſy, which men of wit ſeldom want.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Lord, Madam, what ſhou'd you do with a fool to your huſband? You intend to be honeſt, don't you? Then that huſbandly virtue, credulity, is thrown away upon you.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: He only that cou'd ſuſpect my virtue, ſhou'd have cauſe to do it; 'tis Sparkiſh's confidence in my truth, that obliges me to be faithful to him.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: What, faithful to a creature who is incapable of loving and eſteeming you as he ought!—To throw away your beauty, wit, accompliſhments, ſweet temper—

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: Hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: That you know I can't do, Madam; and upon this occaſion, I will talk for ever.—What, give yourſelf away to one, that poor I, your maid, would not accept of?

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: How, Lucy!

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I would not, upon my honour, Madam; 'tis never too late to repent. Take a man, and give up your coxcomb, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mr. Sparkiſh, with company, Madam, attends you below.

sp.speaker: Alith.
sp.p: I will wait upon 'em. [Exit Servant.] My heart begins to fail me, but I muſt go through with it; go with me, Lucy.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
